title: How to Grill Tenderloin

steps.headline: Salt and set the tenderloin steaks out for 20 to 30 minutes.
steps.description: Remove 3 to 4 beef tenderloin steaks from the refrigerator. Open the package and set the steaks on a plate for 20 to 30 minutes, so they aren't chilly and will cook evenly. Sprinkle the steaks with salt to taste.

steps.headline: Heat a grill to medium heat.
steps.description: Turn a gas grill on to medium heat. If you're using a charcoal grill, fill a chimney half to three-quarters full of briquettes and light them. Dump the hot briquettes on one half of the grate to set up a two-zone fire.

steps.headline: Grill the tenderloin steaks for 5 to 6 minutes.
steps.description: Arrange the steaks on the grill over indirect heat, if you're using a charcoal grill. Close the lid and grill the steaks for 5 to 6 minutes without moving them.

steps.headline: Turn and spread sauce on the tenderloin steaks.
steps.description: Open the lid of the grill and use tongs to flip the steaks over. Dip a barbecue brush into a bowl of smoky barbecue sauce or steak sauce. Spread a thin layer of the sauce over the tenderloin steaks and put the lid on the grill.

steps.headline: Grill the tenderloin steaks for 3 to 4 minutes.
steps.description: Keep the lid on the grill and continue to cook the tenderloin steaks. Use the lower cooking times for a medium-rare steak. If you want the tenderloin steaks cooked rare, grill them for a minute less than recommended.

steps.headline: Brush the steaks with sauce and char them for 2 minutes.
steps.description: Open the lid and turn the tenderloin steaks over. Dip the brush in more sauce and spread another thin layer over the steaks. Put the lid on and grill the steaks until they've charred just a little bit. This should take 2 minutes.

steps.headline: Remove the steaks and season them with pepper.
steps.description: Remove the lid from the grill and use tongs to transfer the steaks to a plate. Sprinkle the steaks with a little ground pepper, if desired.

steps.headline: Rest the tenderloin steaks for 8 to 10 minutes before you serve them.
steps.description: Lay a sheet of aluminum foil over the steaks and let the steaks rest. They'll finish cooking and the juices will redistribute within the meat. If you grilled small tenderloin steaks, serve them whole or slice them into thin strips and serve them. Consider serving the meat with extra barbecue or steak sauce. You can store leftover tenderloin steaks in an airtight container in the refrigerator for 3 to 4 days.

methods.name: Cooking Garlic and Herb Whole Beef Tenderloin

steps.headline: Trim and tie the beef tenderloin.
steps.description: Cut open a 4 to 5 pound (1.8 to 2.2 kg) package of whole beef tenderloin. Take a sharp knife cut away fat that's visible on the surface of the meat. Slide the tip of your knife blade under the silver membrane to loosen it a little. Use your fingers to pull away and discard the silver membrane. Fold the thinner end of the tenderloin under itself and tie it in place with butcher twine. You may need to make 5 to 6 ties for the whole piece of meat. The ties will keep the meat in place.

steps.headline: Mix together the garlic and herb marinade.
steps.description: Thinly slice 6 cloves of garlic and place them in a small prep bowl. Crack 2 tablespoons (14 g) of black pepper into the bowl along with 2 teaspoons (4 g) of chopped marjoram, 2 teaspoons (1 g) of fresh chopped rosemary, and 2 tablespoons (36 g) of kosher salt. Pour 1/3 cup (80 ml) of extra-virgin olive oil over the herbs. Use a whisk to combine the marinade.

steps.headline: Rub the meat with the marinade and chill it for 2 to 4 hours.
steps.description: Scoop all of the marinade over the trimmed tenderloin. Use your fingers to rub the marinade over the entire tenderloin. Set the meat on a tray and refrigerate it for 2 to 4 hours.

steps.headline: Prepare your grill for high heat.
steps.description: Turn a gas grill on to medium-high heat. If you want to use a charcoal grill, heat a chimney full of briquettes. Dump the hot coals directly onto the grate.

steps.headline: Turn the tenderloin frequently and grill it for 25 to 30 minutes.
steps.description: Lay the marinated beef tenderloin on the grill directly over the coals, if you're using charcoal. Cover the grill and let the tenderloin cook until it's charred on the outside. Remove the lid and turn it occasionally so it grills evenly.

steps.headline: Check the temperature of the tenderloin.
steps.description: Open the lid of the grill and insert an instant read meat thermometer into the thickest part of the meat. After 25 to 30 minutes, the tenderloin should be at about 145 °F (63 °C). For medium-rare, reduce the grilling time by about 5 minutes. For medium-well cook until it reaches 150 °F (66 °C).

steps.headline: Rest the tenderloin for 10 minutes before you serve it.
steps.description: Move the grilled beef tenderloin to a carving board or platter. Cover it loosely with a sheet of aluminum foil and let it rest for 10 minutes. Slice the meat into ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) thick slices and serve them immediately. You can store leftover tenderloin steaks in an airtight container in the refrigerator for 3 to 4 days.

steps.headline: Mix together the coconut marinade.
steps.description:
Pour one 14-ounce (400 ml) can of unsweetened coconut milk into a small bowl. Zest 1 lime into the bowl and squeeze in 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of the lime's juice. Stir together the liquids and whisk in:
1 heaping tablespoon (6 g) of mild curry powder
1 teaspoon (2 g) of mild Spanish paprika
6 finely chopped garlic cloves
3 tablespoons (18 g) of peeled and grated ginger
1 chopped scotch bonnet or 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of scotch bonnet hot sauce
¼ teaspoon (0.5 g) of coarsely ground black pepper

steps.headline: Coat the pork tenderloin and marinate it for at least 2 hours.
steps.description: Lay a 2-pound (907 g) whole pork tenderloin in a shallow baking dish about 2 inches (5.1 cm). Pour the coconut marinade over the meat and turn it, so the tenderloin is completely coated. Cover the dish with plastic wrap and refrigerate the tenderloin for at least 2 hours. You can marinate the tenderloin for up to 8 hours.

steps.headline: Heat a grill to high heat.
steps.description: Turn a gas grill on to high heat. If you're using a charcoal grill, fill a chimney full of briquettes and light them. Dump the hot briquettes on one half of the grate to set up a two-zone fire.

steps.headline: Set the tenderloin at room temperature for 30 minutes and dry it.
steps.description: Remove the marinated pork tenderloin from the refrigerator and set it out on the counter to take the chill off. Blot the meat dry with paper towels.

steps.headline: Season the pork tenderloin and place it on the grill.
steps.description: Dip a brush in 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of canola oil and brush it over all sides of the meat. Sprinkle the tenderloin with kosher salt and lay it on the grill so it's directly over the coals, if you're using charcoal.

steps.headline: Turn the tenderloin every few minutes for a total of 8 minutes.
steps.description: Cover the grill and cook the meat until it chars a little. Use long tongs to turn the tenderloin every couple of minutes, so the meat cooks evenly.

steps.headline: Grill the tenderloin over indirect heat for 12 minutes.
steps.description: Use tongs to move the tenderloin to the cooler side of the grill and put the lid on the grill. Grill the tenderloin for another 12 minutes and turn it a few times as it grills so it cooks evenly.

steps.headline: Check the temperature of the tenderloin.
steps.description: Insert an instant read meat thermometer into the thickest part of the tenderloin. Once it reaches 150 °F (66 °C), take the tenderloin off of the grill. Set it on a plate or cutting board.

steps.headline: Tent the tenderloin with foil and rest it for 10 minutes.
steps.description: Lay a sheet of aluminum foil loosely over the tenderloin and set it aside for 10 minutes. The tenderloin will finish cooking as it rests.

steps.headline: Slice and serve the pork tenderloin.
steps.description: Use a sharp knife to slice the tenderloin into 0.25 inches (0.64 cm) thick slices. Serve the coconut pork tenderloin immediately or store it in an airtight container. Refrigerate the tenderloin for 3 to 4 days.

Open the lid and turn the tenderloin steaks over. Dip the brush in more sauce and spread another thin layer over the steaks. Put the lid on and grill the steaks until they've charred just a little bit. This should take 2 minutes. Remove the steaks and season them with pepper. Remove the lid from the grill and use tongs to transfer the steaks to a plate. Sprinkle the steaks with a little ground pepper, if desired. Consider serving the meat with extra barbecue or steak sauce. You can store leftover tenderloin steaks in an airtight container in the refrigerator for 3 to 4 days. Take a sharp knife cut away fat that's visible on the surface of the meat. Slide the tip of your knife blade under the silver membrane to loosen it a little. Thinly slice 6 cloves of garlic and place them in a small prep bowl. Crack 2 tablespoons (14 g) of black pepper into the bowl along with 2 teaspoons (4 g) of chopped marjoram, 2 teaspoons (1 g) of fresh chopped rosemary, and 2 tablespoons (36 g) of kosher salt. Pour 1/3 cup (80 ml) of extra-virgin olive oil over the herbs. Use a whisk to combine the marinade. Rub the meat with the marinade and chill it for 2 to 4 hours. Scoop all of the marinade over the trimmed tenderloin. Use your fingers to rub the marinade over the entire tenderloin. Set the meat on a tray and refrigerate it for 2 to 4 hours. Prepare your grill for high heat. Turn a gas grill on to medium-high heat. If you want to use a charcoal grill, heat a chimney full of briquettes. Dump the hot coals directly onto the grate. Turn the tenderloin frequently and grill it for 25 to 30 minutes. Lay the marinated beef tenderloin on the grill directly over the coals, if you're using charcoal. Cover the grill and let the tenderloin cook until it's charred on the outside. Remove the lid and turn it occasionally so it grills evenly. Check the temperature of the tenderloin. Open the lid of the grill and insert an instant read meat thermometer into the thickest part of the meat. After 25 to 30 minutes, the tenderloin should be at about 145 °F (63 °C). For medium-rare, reduce the grilling time by about 5 minutes. For medium-well cook until it reaches 150 °F (66 °C). Rest the tenderloin for 10 minutes before you serve it. Move the grilled beef tenderloin to a carving board or platter. Cover it loosely with a sheet of aluminum foil and let it rest for 10 minutes. Grilling Coconut Marinated Pork Tenderloin Mix together the coconut marinade. Pour one 14-ounce (400 ml) can of unsweetened coconut milk into a small bowl. Zest 1 lime into the bowl and squeeze in 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of the lime's juice. Stir together the liquids and whisk in:
1 heaping tablespoon (6 g) of mild curry powder
1 teaspoon (2 g) of mild Spanish paprika
6 finely chopped garlic cloves
3 tablespoons (18 g) of peeled and grated ginger
1 chopped scotch bonnet or 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of scotch bonnet hot sauce
¼ teaspoon (0.5 g) of coarsely ground black pepper Coat the pork tenderloin and marinate it for at least 2 hours. Lay a 2-pound (907 g) whole pork tenderloin in a shallow baking dish about 2 inches (5.1 cm). Pour the coconut marinade over the meat and turn it, so the tenderloin is completely coated. Cover the dish with plastic wrap and refrigerate the tenderloin for at least 2 hours. You can marinate the tenderloin for up to 8 hours. Heat a grill to high heat. Turn a gas grill on to high heat. If you're using a charcoal grill, fill a chimney full of briquettes and light them. Dump the hot briquettes on one half of the grate to set up a two-zone fire. Set the tenderloin at room temperature for 30 minutes and dry it. Remove the marinated pork tenderloin from the refrigerator and set it out on the counter to take the chill off. Blot the meat dry with paper towels. Season the pork tenderloin and place it on the grill. Dip a brush in 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of canola oil and brush it over all sides of the meat. Sprinkle the tenderloin with kosher salt and lay it on the grill so it's directly over the coals, if you're using charcoal. Turn the tenderloin every few minutes for a total of 8 minutes. Cover the grill and cook the meat until it chars a little. Use long tongs to turn the tenderloin every couple of minutes, so the meat cooks evenly. Grill the tenderloin over indirect heat for 12 minutes. Use tongs to move the tenderloin to the cooler side of the grill and put the lid on the grill. Grill the tenderloin for another 12 minutes and turn it a few times as it grills so it cooks evenly. Check the temperature of the tenderloin.
